title: Sleep and Health
body:
**Key Facts:**
Getting enough sleep supports students’ overall health and well-being. Adequate nightly sleep helps students stay focused, improves concentration, and boosts academic performance. Good sleep hygiene, combined with later school start times, helps adolescents stay healthier and perform better academically.

**Overview:**
Children and adolescents who do not get enough sleep are at higher risk for obesity, type 2 diabetes, poor mental health, and injuries. Insufficient sleep is also linked to attention and behavior problems, leading to poorer school performance.

**Sleep needs by age:**
The American Academy of Sleep Medicine recommends:
- **Ages 6–12:** 9–12 hours of sleep per 24 hours
- **Ages 13–18:** 8–10 hours of sleep per 24 hours

**Insufficient sleep among students:**
2015 Youth Risk Behavior Surveys found:
- **Middle school (grades 6–8) students in 9 states:** 57.8% did not get enough sleep on school nights.
- **High school (grades 9–12) students nationwide:** 72.7% did not get enough sleep on school nights.

**Recommendations:**
In 2014, the American Academy of Pediatrics recommended that middle and high schools start no earlier than 8:30 AM so adolescents can get the sleep they need. The American Medical Association, the American Academy of Sleep Medicine, and other medical organizations also support delaying school start times for adolescents.
